item.title: Progressive web apps for Noobs
item.description:
The web is changing so fast that itâ€™s difficult for every developer to learn each and every new technologies, but there are many latest tech that developers should not miss and PWAs (Progressive web apps) are one of them.

ðŸ¤” But what are PWAs?

Progressive web apps are the web apps which look like native apps. PWAs uses latest browserâ€™s APIs to extend their features and provide a native app like experience.

Here are the features of PWAs ðŸ˜Ž:

  • Responsive - It works on every device like Mobile, Desktop, or Tablets or whatever is next
  • App Like - PWAs will just feel like native mobile apps because the shell and content are seprated
  • Updated - Always stays fresh, because service workers keeps the content on the page up-to-date
  • Safe - Progressive web apps work over https so all the data transfered over the network is encrypted
  • Installable - PWAs can be installed just like native apps are installed on Operating System
  • Notifications - Thanks to the browser APIs and Service Workers, users can recieve notifications.

...and what is Service Worker?

Service workers are the worker scripts which works in background for the web app. They are very powerful technology behind PWAs and handle push notifications, cache web app's content, make web app to work offline and lot more

In other words, service workers are just a javascript file that works independent of webapp and in background and it is up to you to write code for notification, content caching, etc

Service workers are available on Android with chrome 50 or higher and not supported by some major browsers but developers are working to bring it on different platforms and browsers.

Appshell

Appshell is not a framework or library, itâ€™s just a design approach that developers can choose to adhere to that is enhanced by the caching abilities of service workers. It is loaded at the beginning of the page load and the content is loaded afterward.

Service worker caches the appshell and makes the web app load quicker after the first load. This improves the overall app experience.

Installability and App Manifest

One of the best features of PWAs is user can install the app just from the browser. Before installed PWA was placed on the home screen but now user can install them just like native apps and will appear in apps drawer too. Like native apps, you can uninstall the PWAs too.

To make the app installable we link manifest.json file to our main HTML page. (See how manifest.json is written)

Useful Links
- If you want to learn more about progressive web apps, visit the google's official documentation
- Lighthouse is a tool used to improve the quality of PWAs
- pwa.rocks is directory of cool progressive web apps

Conclusion

At Techies.pro, we believe that Progressive Web apps are the future of web apps, at some time they will replace the native web apps. Itâ€™s just the initial stage of this technology, with time this will get more mature and will be adopted by all major browsers.
